Tests to compare covariance matrices

Source: vignettes/Tests_Sigmas.Rmd
Tests_Sigmas.Rmd
library(stests)

Introduction

Let ğ—1i,ğ—2i,â€¦,ğ—Nii\mathbf{X}_{1i}, \mathbf{X}_{2i}, \ldots, \mathbf{X}_{N_i i} be a random sample from the population Np(ğ›g,ğšºg)N_p(\boldsymbol{\mu}_g, \boldsymbol{\Sigma}_g) indexed by i=1,2,â€¦,gi = 1,2,\ldots,g. In other words, we have gg samples as follows

ğ—11,ğ—21,â€¦,ğ—N11ğ—12,ğ—22,â€¦,ğ—N22â‹®ğ—1g,ğ—2g,â€¦,ğ—Ngg \begin{matrix} \mathbf{X}_{11}, \mathbf{X}_{21}, \ldots, \mathbf{X}_{N_1 1} \\ \mathbf{X}_{12}, \mathbf{X}_{22}, \ldots, \mathbf{X}_{N_2 2} \\ \vdots \\ \mathbf{X}_{1g}, \mathbf{X}_{2g}, \ldots, \mathbf{X}_{N_g g} \end{matrix}

It is not necessary to have equal NiN_i. The main objective in this vignette is to use test to study the following hypothesis.

H0:Î£1=Î£2=â‹¯=Î£g=Î£ H_{0}: \Sigma_{1} = \Sigma_{2} = \cdots = \Sigma_{g} = \Sigma

HA:at least one Î£ is different H_{A}: \text{at least one } \Sigma \text{ is different}

Box-M test

Box (1949) proposed this test and the statistic test Ï†\varphi is given by:

Ï†=âˆ’2Ïlog(Î») \varphi = -2 \rho \log(\lambda)

Under true H0H_{0}, the statistic

Ï†âˆ¼Ï‡p(p+1)(gâˆ’1)/22 \varphi \sim \chi^{2}_{p(p+1)(g-1)/2}

Where Ï\rho, log(Î»)\log(\lambda) and SS are obtained by as

Ï=1âˆ’2p2+3pâˆ’16(p+1)(gâˆ’1)(âˆ‘i=1g1niâˆ’1n) \rho = 1 - \frac{2p^{2} + 3p - 1}{6(p + 1)(g - 1)} \left( \sum_{i=1}^{g} \frac{1}{n_i} - \frac{1}{n} \right)

log(Î»)=nlog(|S|)âˆ’âˆ‘i=1gnilog(|Si|)âˆ’2 \log(\lambda) = \frac{n \, \log(|S|) - \sum_{i=1}^{g} n_i \, \log(|S_i|)}{-2}

S=1nâˆ‘i=1gniSi S = \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{g} n_i S_i

with

ni=Niâˆ’1 n_i = N_i - 1

n=n1+n2+â€¦ng n = n_1 + n_2 + \ldots n_g

This test seems to be good if each NiN_i exceeds 20, and if gg and pp do not exceed 5 (Mardia, Bibby, and Kent (1992), page 140).

Bartlettâ€™s test or modified LRT

xxx proposed this test and the statistic is given by:

M=nlog(|S|)âˆ’âˆ‘i=1gnilog(|Si|) M = n \log(|S|) - \sum_{i=1}^{g} n_i \log(|S_i|)

Under true H0H_{0}, the statistic

Mâˆ¼Ï‡p(p+1)(gâˆ’1)/22 M \sim \chi^{2}_{p(p+1)(g-1)/2}

The matrix SS and nn are the same as in the Box-M test.

Note: Schott (2007) claims that since the sample covariance matrix SiS_i is singular if ni<pn_i < p, this likelihood ratio test is valid only if niâ‰¥pn_i \ge p for i=1,2,â€¦,gi = 1,2, \ldots, g.

Wald Schott test

Schott (2001) (page 27) proposed this test and the statistic is given by:

W=n2{âˆ‘i=1gnintr(SiSâˆ’1SiSâˆ’1)âˆ’âˆ‘i=1gâˆ‘j=1gninjn2tr(SiSâˆ’1SjSâˆ’1)}. W = \frac{n}{2} \left\{ \sum_{i=1}^{g} \frac{n_i}{n} \, \mathrm{tr}(S_i S^{-1} S_i S^{-1}) - \sum_{i=1}^{g} \sum_{j=1}^{g} \frac{n_i n_j}{n^{2}} \, \mathrm{tr}(S_i S^{-1} S_j S^{-1}) \right\}.

Under true H0H_{0}, the statistic

Wâˆ¼Ï‡p(p+1)(gâˆ’1)/22 W \sim \chi^{2}_{p(p+1)(g-1)/2}

The matrix SS and nn are the same as in the Box-M test.
